topic.title: Adding a New Ceph Monitor Node

body.note: Hyperlinks intermittently do not work in the Google Chrome browser. Click here for a frameless version of this page where the links should work.

section.p: In , a Ceph monitor node is installed on the controller nodes by default. A new monitor node cannot be added to an existing Ceph cluster if Ceph is deployed with the default configuration. However, if monitor nodes are added on a dedicated resource node, then you can add a new monitor node.
If a monitor resource is not already defined, you will need to first define one and then add the new monitor node. For instructions, see .

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: You should have one or more baremetal servers that meet the minimum hardware requirements for a Ceph node which are documented in the Hardware Support Matrix.

section.title: Adding a Ceph Monitor Node
section.p: These steps will show you how to add the new Ceph monitor node to your servers.yml file and then run the playbooks that update your cloud configuration. You will run these playbooks from the lifecycle manager.

ol.li: Log in to your lifecycle manager.
Checkout the site branch of your local git so you can begin to make the necessary edits: cd ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data git checkout site

In the same directory, edit your servers.yml file to include the Ceph monitor nodes. Copy and paste the section for an existing server having the MON-ROLE role and edit the values to match the new server being added.
Here is an example:- id: mon4 ip-addr: 192.168.10.11 role: MON-ROLE server-group: RACK3 nic-mapping: MY-2PORT-SERVER mac-addr: 8b:f6:9e:ca:3b:7a ilo-ip: 192.168.9.11 ilo-password: password ilo-user: admin
You can find detailed descriptions of these fields here. You will need to verify that the ip-addr value you choose for this node does not conflict with any other IP address in your cloud environment. You can confirm this by checking the ~/helion/my_cloud/info/address_info.yml file on your lifecycle manager.

In your control_plane.yml file you will need to check the values for member-count, min-count, and max-count, if you specified them, to ensure that they match up with your new total node count. So for example, if you had previously specified member-count: 3 and are adding a fourth Ceph monitor node, you will need to change that value to member-count: 4.
See Input Model - Control Plane for more details.
Commit the changes to git: git commit -a -m "Add node <name>"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the ready deployment playbook: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Add the new node into Cobbler: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml

Then you can image the node: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=<node name> If you don't know the <node name> already, you can get it by using sudo cobbler system list
Before proceeding, you may want to take a look at info/server_info.yml to see if the assignment of the node you have added is what you expect. It may not be, as nodes will not be numbered consecutively if any have previously been removed. This is to prevent loss of data; the config processor retains data about removed nodes and keeps their ID numbers from being reallocated. See the Persisted Server Allocations section in
Input Model for information on how this works.

Run the following series of playbooks complete the deployment of your additional Ceph monitor node(s) to your Ceph cluster: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --tags "generate_hosts_file" ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --limit <hostname>
The hostname of the newly added node can be found in the list generated from the output of the following command: grep hostname ~/helion/my_cloud/info/server_info.yml
